    smoothToSigmaZeroPointSevenOne(Image input)
    Uses the first step of an A Trous wavelet transform, which is two 1D convolutions of a binomial kernel for sigma=0.707 (=sqrt(2)/2).

    • calculateWithTriangleScalingFunction

      public void calculateWithTriangleScalingFunction(GreyscaleImage input, List<GreyscaleImage> outputTransformed, List<GreyscaleImage> outputCoeff)
      The a trous algorithm is a fast implementation of a wavelet transform with no downsampling. It is non-orthogonal, semi-linear runtime complexity, is invariant under translation, and the transform is isotropic. Implemented from pseudocode in http://www.multiresolution.com/svbook.pdf The scaling function used is the lower resolution choice, the triangle function. 
       The method uses recursive convolution operations, including previous
 result to make next.
 Each convolution uses two passes of one dimensional binomial kernels,
 starting with the equivalent of sigma=sqrt(2)/2 = 0.707.
 For each step, the equivalent resulting sigma is from 
 sigma^2 = sigma_1^2 + sigma_2^2.
 
 outputTransformed[1] = sigma=sqrt(2)/2 convolution
 outputTransformed[2] = sigma=1 convolution
 outputTransformed[3] = sqrt( (1)^2 + 1/2) = sqrt(1 + 1/2) convolution
 outputTransformed[4] = sqrt( 1 + 1/2 + 1/2) = sqrt(2)
 outputTransformed[5] = sqrt( 2 + 1/2)       = sqrt(2.5)
 outputTransformed[6] = sqrt( 2 + 1/2 + 1/2) = sqrt(3)
  ...
      Parameters:
      input -
      outputTransformed -
      outputCoeff -

    • calculateWithB3SplineScalingFunction

      public void calculateWithB3SplineScalingFunction(GreyscaleImage input, List<GreyscaleImage> outputTransformed, List<GreyscaleImage> outputCoeff)
      The a trous algorithm is a fast implementation of a wavelet transform with no downsampling. It is non-orthogonal, has semi-linear runtime complexity, is invariant under translation, and the transform is isotropic. Implemented from pseudocode in http://www.multiresolution.com/svbook.pdf The scaling function used is the higher resolution choice, the 3rd order B Spline function. 
       The method uses recursive convolution operations, including previous
 result to make next.
 Each convolution uses two passes of one dimensional binomial kernels,
 starting with the equivalent of sigma=1.
 For each step, the equivalent resulting sigma is from 
 sigma^2 = sigma_1^2 + sigma_2^2.
 
 outputTransformed[1] = sigma = 1 convolution
 outputTransformed[2] = sqrt( (1)^2 + (1)^2 ) = sqrt(2) convolution
 outputTransformed[3] = sqrt( 2 + 1 ) = sqrt(3) convolution
 outputTransformed[4] = sqrt( 3 + 1 ) = sqrt(4) = 2 convolution
 outputTransformed[5] = sqrt( 4 + 1 ) = sqrt(5) convolution
 outputTransformed[6] = sqrt( 5 + 1 ) = sqrt(6) convolution
 ...
 outputTransformed[8] = sqrt( 8 + 1 ) = sqrt(9) = 3 convolution
      Parameters:
      input -
      outputTransformed -
      outputCoeff -

    • calculateWithB3SplineScalingFunction

      public void calculateWithB3SplineScalingFunction(GreyscaleImage input, List<GreyscaleImage> outputTransformed, List<GreyscaleImage> outputCoeff, int stopIter)
      The a trous algorithm is a fast implementation of a wavelet transform with no downsampling. It is non-orthogonal, has semi-linear runtime complexity, is invariant under translation, and the transform is isotropic. Implemented from pseudocode in http://www.multiresolution.com/svbook.pdf The scaling function used is the higher resolution choice, the 3rd order B Spline function. 
       The method uses recursive convolution operations, including previous
 result to make next.
 
 This method takes an argument stopIter to indicate that only stopIter
 number of iterations are needed.  For instance, to retrieve only the
 first populated wavelet, use stopIter = 2 (the first is initialization,
 and the second is the calculation).
      Parameters:
      input -
      outputTransformed -
      outputCoeff -
      stopIter -

    • calculateWithB3SplineScalingFunction2

      void calculateWithB3SplineScalingFunction2(GreyscaleImage input, List<GreyscaleImage> outputTransformed, List<GreyscaleImage> outputCoeff)
      same as calculateWithB3SplineScalingFunction except that it uses a 2-D scaling function and the runtime is 2.5 times longer.
      Parameters:

      outputTransformed -
